When you covered the environmental impact of rockets you didn't mention the impact of the Saturn 5 on the ozone layer. Apparently it would burn a hole through the ozone layer that took a couple weeks to close up again; this means basically that the ozone layer was thinning to disperse and fill the void. This is an important environmental impact as the ozone layer determines the atmospheric oxygen concentration. Since the age of dinosaurs all living things have gradually become smaller and smaller because the ozone layer is naturally thinning slowly with time; in fact atmospheric oxygen is depleting with time. The thinner layer today makes it harder for the metabolism of a larger animal to survive; being small makes metabolism easier. If we thin the ozone layer at a faster rate than the natural rate it could impact our metabolism negatively. We are concerned with the depletion of atmospheric oxygen, biological oxygen demand (BOD5), in addition to green house gasses and other impacts when completing a Life Cycle Assessment model. I would recommend making a video regarding the environmental impacts using the LCA model standardized in engineering; following the full model you should include the impacts of manufacturing the rocket parts, the fuel, the depletion of any resources, the energy consumed, the impacts along the way, and the disposal method and final destination. It is not adequate to simply study the impact of the fuel type or combustion process in different engines alone.

For example an aluminum can does not impact the environment seriously being burned, or in it's actual use. However, to actually make an aluminum can from raw material requires a large quantity of electrical energy and generating that energy has significant impacts that need to be factored into the impact of the aluminum can. Compared to the can's disposal and use, the manufacturing and refining of raw material is significantly more impactful.

I sort of wonder about the effect of forces from turbulence on the structure of the carbon fiber. No argument, the stuff is strong but it's also very rigid, so stuff like turbulence which can produce a lot of repeated torsional stresses which can eventually lead to de-lamination. Meaning they'll have to do something like xray the whole structure to look for hidden voids, and if they find any, toss the whole thing (no way to spot fix carbon fiber), but I guess they at least could still reuse tanks and engines? I guess this is all a long way of saying that I'm VERY CURIOUS about what the referb process might look like if it does manage to make it that far and how they hope to tune the referb process to make it a net win as far as overall cost. Making refurb a net win on cost was a long road for spaceX, and that is a WAY easier problem (repulsive re-entry and materials which are less ridged so less prone to permanent deformation from stress).

I literally just had this idea, except about catching model rockets in the sky with a net carried by 3 drones, similar to what Raffaello D'Andrea did in his TED talk about the athletic ability of quadcopters. I thought, too, "That sounds like something SpaceX would do". But then I thought of the physics of it. When catching a model rocket with drones holding a net, the net has a tremendous amount of "give" (vertical distance) therefore require less force to bring the rocket to a net 0 acceleration. (Work = Force * Distance). In a SpaceX rocket, however, the engines are already there. The flight computer is already there. You can put landing legs on it. So while it's cool to catch a rocket with a flying computer, it really doesn't make sense to make another flying computer to catch another flying computer. But the novelty of the challenge is still there.

Two thoughts: One, the USAF routinely recovered its parachute-lowered Firebee jet-powered target drones using a helicopter; the system was called MARS (Mid-Air Retrieval System), and their current Firebee replacement targets may also utilize MARS recovery. Also:


While this is more speculative, the small size (and therefore higher strength and rigidity) of the Electron first stage may--if they're going to do this--make it possible to launch the vehicle from a tube launcher, with a sealing piston entrapping the engines' exhaust in order to "pop" the vehicle into flight. (The Arcas and Super Arcas meteorological and sounding rockets were also tube-launched in this way, and the piston launcher [the rockets sat atop the piston, with plastic foam staves aligning them in the tube] significantly increased their launch velocity without requiring a booster to be added. One or two optional additional gas generator cartridges could also be threaded into the launcher's bottom plenum chamber and fired at ignition, to enable heavier payloads to be carried--or to achieve even higher launch velocities with normal-mass Arcas and Super Arcas payloads.) Most liquid propellant rockets are too large and fragile to survive such high launch accelerations, but the Electron is a quite small, strong, and stiff vehicle, so such tube launches would likely be survivable.

Mid-air recovery systems (MARS) is a proven recovery system.  We used it throughout the Viet Nam war with the drone reconnaissance missions. Our drones had no wheels, (nearly) all were recovered using specially equipped helicopters which would catch the parachute, winch it up and would lower it onto equipment cradles at the recovery station.  There were the occasional misses, but most were recovered.  Our drones were a lot heavier than what Rocket Lab is planning to use.

I hadnt thought about helicopter recovery before these recent announcements by Rocket Lab. It got me thinking about the scalability of helicopters; and I think where you get stuck is how to turn the thing around as you scale it up. Youd be looking at insane torque at glacial RPM; whereas efficient and power dense turbines go the exact opposite way. So rockets at the tips was apparently one idea NASA had... but it sounds iffy, putting all that mass of your engines and fuel at the tips of your blades, and also a control nightmare.

But why not an autogyro? Wouldnt that scale to pretty crazy sizes using nowadays relatively 'standard' windmill production technology? Just slap on some standard forward thrust and there you go. It should allow for near-zero-forward-speed catches and landings, and frankly should scale to pretty ridiculous sizes and loads I think. That said exactly how to land it without crushing your load isnt obvious either. Drop the payload in a net using a touch-and-go, and then find a place to put your giant windmill down again?

Let's see if the current block of the Electron rocket would be able to use propulsive landing without dropping their payload down to zero:
Assuming that its current peak velocity of 7,500 km/h (2,083.[3] m/s) is the delta-V it will need to have to propulsively land† and its average specific impulse during the process is ~295 seconds‡, the rocket equation dictates that the fuel needed for propulsive landing will mass about the same as of the empty 1st stage. With 100 kg extra for landing legs, etc, this would mean an increase in 1st stage effective dry mass from 950 kg to 2100 kg.


Now let's plug this into Silverbird Astronautics to estimate its payload capacity to a 170 km orbit at minimum inclination from Mahia:
109 kg. So yes, it is almost certainly possible for the Electron to deliver a payload into orbit with propulsive landing, but such payload would have to be somewhat smaller.


†With propulsive landing it will have a lower peak velocity, but gravity drag and 2 burns will need to be taken into account. In truth, this is probably still well above the delta-V needed, but it's best to be conservative.
‡Entry burn takes majority of delta-V at vacuum Isp (303 seconds), landing burn takes small fraction of delta-V at sea level Isp (~270 seconds).

Maybe Rocket Lab will split the Electron design into two models, one model fully expendable for heavy payloads or difficult orbits, and the other model recoverable and reusable for lighter payloads or easier orbits. At a drop zone by the town of Frederick in Colorado in 1980, a guy who had only recently recovered from a broken leg (Steve Johnston) was setting up for his landing when another jumper (Tim Monsees) spiraled down, landed, threw off his rig, and ran over, hands in the air. "Steve! Steve! Here! Here!" Steve flared and Tim caught him, placing him on his feet to a round of applause.

If that can be done with the Mk I human eyeball, it can be done with differential GPS and a cooperative target with clever software.

Steve died a few months later in the Loveland, CO midair on Apr 17, 1981.
